FRBRalias.value: The Central Provinces And Berar Regulation Of Couching Act, 1944

p.shortTitle: The Central Provinces And Berar Regulation Of Couching Act, 1944

longTitle.p: C.P. and Berar Act No. II of 1944
An Act to prevent couching by unqualified persons.
WHEREAS it is expedient to prevent couching by unqualified persons;
It is hereby enacted as follows: —

content.p: This Act may be cited as the Central Provinces and Berar Regulation of Couching Act, 1944.
It extends to the whole of the State of Maharashtra.

blockList.listIntroduction: In this Act, the expression "registered practitioner" means & person registered under—

item.p: the Bombay Medical Act, 1912 (Bom. VI of 1912);
the Central Provinces and Berar Medical Registration Act, 1916 (U.P. And Berar I of 1916);
the Medical Registration Act (of 1348 Fasli) (Hyd. I of 1348)
the Indian Medical Council Act, 1956 (Fasli. CIT of 1956); or

any other law for the time being in force in the State, which regulates the registration and practice of practitioners, and who possesses such qualifications for the practice of surgery as the State Government may, for the purposes of this Act by notification in the Official Gazette, recognise.

content.p: Notwithstanding anything contained in any other law, whoever, not being a registered practitioner, or not possessing qualifications entitling him to be a registered practitioner, couches or attempts to couch or agrees or offers by physical means or interference with the eye to give vision to a person suffering from cataract, with or without that person's consent, shall, on conviction, be punishable with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees or with both.
Whoever abets the commission of an offence under this Act shall, on conviction, be punishable with the punishment provided for the offence in section 3.

section.heading: Offence to be cognizable, bailable and compoundable. —

content.p: Notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 (V of 1898), an offence punishable under this Act shall be cognizable and bailable and may be compounded with the permission of the Court.
No Magistrate having powers inferior to that of a Presidency Magistrate or a Magistrate of the first class shall try any offence punishable under this Act.

blockList.listIntroduction: A Magistrate may take cognizance of an offence under this Act—

item.p: on a report of a police officer;
on information of any other person;
upon his own knowledge or suspicion that such offence has been committed:

content.p: Provided that no cognizance shall be taken where the offence alleged was committed more than six months previously.
